titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Jay F. Rosenberg Papers, 1956-2008 ASP.2008.02
titlestmt.author: Lance Lugar.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2021-06-11 09:39:57 -0400.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

did.abstract: Jay Rosenberg's work focused on such philosophical topics as Epistemology, Metaphysics, Philosophy of Language, History of Philosophy and the philosophy of Wilfrid Sellars. As he worked closely with Wilfrid Sellars, the collection also contains manuscripts, correspondence, and photographs of Sellars, his colleagues at the University of Pittsburgh, and at conferences.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: These papers contain materials relating to the professional life of the American philosopher Jay Rosenberg, including manuscripts of his books and his professional articles, as well as drafts and outlines drawn from his teaching materials used in courses at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. There are also manuscripts that relate to the professional academic talks that he gave at conferences or at other universities, as well as to his administrative activities as a professor at a major research university. There are also letters derived from his professional correspondence. Books and articles from his library and reprint collection have been retained if they contain substantive annotations.

In addition to his own manuscripts and correspondence, the papers contain extensive materials from the work of Wilfrid Sellars, with whom Rosenberg studied while earning his Ph.D. at the University of Pittsburgh. This section of his archive contains photographs of not only Wilfrid Sellars, but other philosphers of science. These were often group photos taken at conferences.

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: Jay Frank Rosenberg was a prominent American philosopher active during the middle 20th century through the early part of the 21st century. He was born on April 18, 1942 in Chicago, Illinois, and died on February 21, 2008 in Chapel Hill, North Carolina. He spent the bulk of his professional career as a Professor of Philosophy at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. He was active as both a researcher and a teacher. His areas of philosophical research included Metaphysics, Epistemology, History of Philosophy, and Philosophy of Language.

Rosenberg was a graduate of Reed College where he earned a B.A. in 1963. He then took his Ph.D. in Philosophy from the University of Pittsburgh. His degree was conferred in 1966. He studied under Wilfrid Sellars. The title of his research dissertation was "A Study of the Determinable - Determinate Relationship."
Rosenberg published extensively over the course of his career and produced ten books and over 80 articles on various topics in philosophy.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Gift of Regina Falten-Rosenberg and Leslie Rosenberg Thompson in 2008.

odd.head: Previous Citation
odd.p: Jay Rosenberg Papers, ASP.2008.02, Archives of Scientific Philosophy, Special Collections Department, University of Pittsburgh

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Jay Rosenberg Papers, ASP.2008.02, Archives of Scientific Philosophy, Archives & Special Collections, University of Pittsburgh Library System

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Rosenberg Papers are arranged into eight series, some of which are divided into sub-series:
Series VI. Library - PrePrints and Reprints (annotated)
Series VII. Rosenberg's Miscellaneous Personal Papers
Series VIII. Wilfrid Sellars's Miscellaneous Personal Papers

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection was preliminarily processed by Tina Zinn (September 2011-February 2012) and by Michael Embree (July 2012-August 2012). Amanda Peters processed the bulk of the material (Sept. 2013-April 2014), finishing the sorting, foldering, and creation of the finding aid. Lance Lugar appraised, analysed and arranged the collection, selecting the series and sub-series categories; he also supervised the work of T. Zinn, M. Embree and A. Peters.

userestrict.head: Copyright
userestrict.p: The University of Pittsburgh holds the property rights to the material in this collection as well as the intellectual rights to all material created by Jay Rosenberg. However, it does not hold the intellectual copyright for materials created by all of the other authors. Researchers using this collection are therefore advised to follow the regulations set forth in the U.S. Copyright Code when publishing, quoting or reproducing material from this collection without obtaining the consent of the creator/author of the material if such activities go beyond what is allowed by the fair use provisions of the Code.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Rosenberg was a very active and productive philosopher. Hence his correspondence reflects the professional activities of a professor of philosophy; the correspondence series includes letters to and from other philosophers, as well as correspondence with publishers, professional societies such as the APA, and administrators.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Rosenberg saved correspondence that Sellars had with various other philosophers, scientists, and scholars. These augment similar letters found in the ASP's Sellars Papers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains manuscripts of professional talks given by Rosenberg. There are Carus Lecture manuscripts, the manuscript of talks on Sellars philosophy, and talks on other philosophical topics.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains philosophical manuscripts written by Rosenberg throughout his professional career. These manuscripts include journal articles, invited book chapters, reviews, and conference papers. Unpublished manuscripts contain mostly handwritten and typed content along with sources Rosenberg may have used during his research and writing process.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Rosenberg taught many different courses during his long career. This section contains manuscripts of his undergraduate and graduate courses at the University of North Carolina. They are arranged by course number, and within series of multiple offerings of the same course, chronologically by year.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The reprints, preprints and other versions of published professional essays are annotated by Rosenberg and kept. Unannotated reprints were not retained.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The Rosenberg Archive also contains a small collection of personal materials including non-professional manuscripts Rosenberg created while studying philosophy as an undergraduate student at Reed College. Other materials include Rosenberg's obituary, a DVD containing a memorial presentation of photographs of Rosenberg, and his curriculum vitae.

did.unittitle: A Note on Tensed Discourse and the Eliminability of the Tenses
The Impoverished Students' Book of Cookery, Drinkery, & Housekeepery
Proceedings and Addresses of the American Philosophical Association Vol. 2, Issue 2, November; Rosenberg's Obituary p. 164
Self, Language, and World: Themes in Philosophy of Jay F. Rosenberg
Wilfrid Sellars' Miscellaneous Personal Papers and Photographs

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Rosenberg was a student of Sellars while working on his Ph.D. at the University of Pittsburgh. They kept up contact throughout the remainder of Sellars' career. Hence this collection contains letters, other documents, and especially photographs that will be of interest to historians and philosophers studying Sellars' philosophy.

did.unittitle: Memorandum of Agreement, R.W. Sellars and Arthur Glasgow
"The Irvine Lexicon" ed. by D.C. Dennett
Sellars' Bibliography compiled by Andrew Chrucky

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The photographs found here are an interesting and useful addition to photographs found in the Sellars Archive. They include multiple photographs of Sellars in early, middle, and later life as well photographs of Sellars and other major philosophers at conferences and conventions.
